title: Considering Oral Immunotherapy?

content: My two boys have been in active treatment with oral immunotherapy (OIT) for three years. They have had two quite different journeys, but I count them both as success stories. They still have a long road with more opportunity for additional wins ahead. Has it been easy? No.  Would I recommend it to others?  Almost always, yes. Has it been worth it? Now, that is a hearty heck yes!

Are you thinking about food allergy treatment? Then this is the article for you. I’m going to share my experience with OIT, including our different, yet both successful, outcomes thus far. I’ll also cover the logistics involved in OIT and what to look for in a treatment center.
Let’s get started!
A Tale of Two (Different, Yet Awesome) Outcomes

My oldest son is the perfect candidate and success story for OIT.  He came into the treatment center with a long list of food allergies and passed several oral food challenges (OFCs) before we picked a list of allergens to treat. We made a plan to treat peanut and cashew, and while he was also allergic to green peas, chickpeas, and lentils, we decided to avoid those for the time being.

They still have a long road with more opportunity for additional wins ahead. Has it been easy? No.  Would I recommend it to others?  Almost always, yes. Has it been worth it? Now, that is a hearty heck yes!

Are you thinking about food allergy treatment? Then this is the article for you. I’m going to share my experience with OIT, including our different, yet both successful, outcomes thus far. I’ll also cover the logistics involved in OIT and what to look for in a treatment center.
Let’s get started!
A Tale of Two (Different, Yet Awesome) Outcomes

My oldest son is the perfect candidate and success story for OIT.  He came into the treatment center with a long list of food allergies and passed several oral food challenges (OFCs) before we picked a list of allergens to treat. We made a plan to treat peanut and cashew, and while he was also allergic to green peas, chickpeas, and lentils, we decided to avoid those for the time being.

content: We chose to begin omalizumab (Xolair) in advance of his treatment, so we started shots two months before his first OIT dose. He had no issues with the drug, and it took him only six months to make it to his first “maintenance” dose of one peanut and one cashew.  We discontinued Xolair once he made it to one nut each, and he maintained no symptoms even when off the biologic. He passed an oral food challenge for a low dose of pistachio (it has a similar protein to cashew, so you usually can gain tolerance to it if you treat cashew allergy). And over time, he doubled his maintenance dose two more times.

He is currently eating four peanuts and four cashews (or eight pistachios) a day. Later this year, he will double his dose yet again, and will then be required to eat this amount three to five days a week, as opposed to the daily regime he’s done until now.

content_blocks.text: We chose to begin omalizumab (Xolair) in advance of his treatment, so we started shots two months before his first OIT dose. He is currently eating four peanuts and four cashews (or eight pistachios) a day. Later this year, he will double his dose yet again, and will then be required to eat this amount three to five days a week, as opposed to the daily regime he’s done until now.

content: This is a MASSIVE WIN. Oh, and by the way, he recently passed OFCs to his other remaining allergens – green pea, chickpea, and lentil.  I’m not sure if he outgrew them or if treating the allergy to peanuts (also legumes) helped his tolerance to these foods. Either way, we are thrilled. He now eats at (almost) all restaurants, is loving his second summer of sleepaway camp, and enjoys a very “normal” life. Of course, he will carry epinephrine forever, and we still ask lots of questions and double-check ingredients of whatever he eats. But the freedom he’s gained and the lowering of anxiety I’ve experienced are both immeasurable.
Another Path: Low and Slow

Now let’s talk about another path. My younger son has always had a much longer list of allergies.  We also started with many oral food challenges before he began treatment. He is on dupilumab (Dupixent) for eczema, so we did not add Xolair to his mix.  We decided to treat five allergens: peanut, cashew, dairy, wheat, and egg. It’s a LOT. But, for us, with a list as long as his, it really did not make sense to us to treat one allergy at a time.  (More on this below.)

content: He has not had an easy road. He had a handful of reactions to doses (some during times when doses were increased, some during daily dosing). We were putting a heavy load on his little body. Most of the time he managed it great. And sometimes the allergy load was just too much. Thankfully, he is absolutely fine, and we have learned so much along the way. He is a trouper, and he always wanted to keep going.

We worked with our amazing treatment team to create a new plan for him which we call “low and slow.” He is staying on oral immunotherapy for his five allergens, but we backed up to a lower level, and we are just taking our sweet time. He’s used the extra months to cross off six more allergens in OFCs (SIX NEW WINS!), and everyone’s stress is lower while he has a busy sports and travel schedule. We will continue to ramp back up again, just more slowly.

content: This may sound complicated; however, I still count his story as a MAJOR WIN. Before treatment, we were all absolutely terrified of specks of food anywhere. We rarely took him to restaurants (even with his own food to eat). We aggressively wiped down airplane seats (or any random seats he would sit in). We had multiple allergens taken out of his classroom. We hosted all playdates at our home. We had everyone wash their hands upon entering our home or before interacting with him. It was a LOT. And it was no way to live. Not only was my anxiety through the roof, but so was his. And by the way, this was not just because we were overreacting. This was mostly due to a horrifying anaphylactic reaction to an accidental gluten exposure in what should have been a safe food. (If you’d like to read that story, it’s on my personal website; the link is in my bio.)

content: We were tired. We were scared. We had to find a better way. And with OIT, even after a few bumps in the road, and even on a lower dose, we all feel a complete reversal in our lives. The stress is (almost) gone; the opportunities are abundant. There is no more wiping everything down and no more requests for allergens to be out of his classroom (or our home). We know that he is safe from contact, and even safe from accidental cross-contamination. I still cook all his food (old habits die hard!), but he joins us at restaurants, and we constantly travel. His future is bright. I know one day he will join his brother in his expanded freedom, and I can’t wait!
The Truth About OIT Logistics

OIT is a lot of work. It can seem overwhelming at the beginning, but I can honestly tell you it becomes just a part of daily life. Your child will need to “dose” every day. There are times you skip – if you travel by air, if your child is sick, if you go to a high elevation, if your child gets a vaccine, etc. But plan on this being a daily part of your lives for many years. Depending on your particular treatment plan and program, you will likely go to your doctor’s office every two weeks or so to “updose,” your OIT, which means increasing your dose of the allergen by a certain amount. Then you will maintain that dose for the following two weeks until you updose again. Specifics can vary, and you should be able to tailor your program to a schedule that works for you, but either way, there will be s lot of time with your allergist.

content: When dosing, your child needs to be well, have a belly full of food, and be calm. In other words, not just running off the sports field. After the dose, they are required to rest for one to two hours, in order to not raise their heart rate and trigger their immune system. This sounds tricky, but for us, we’ve always dosed after dinner when we are in for the night. The boys will do homework or watch TV for a while, and I have a window of two hours to watch them before they go to bed.

Scheduling OIT doses requires thinking ahead, but so does living with food allergies. We stick to our regular routine at home, and sometimes mix it up if we are traveling. We always skip dosing on a travel day and often dose OIT in the morning with breakfast instead of at night.  While the boys have a chill morning (their two-hour rest period), my husband and I will do a little work or sneak in some exercise. Then, we are ready to explore and have fun for the rest of the day as a family, without worrying about OIT. You should be able to create a schedule that works for your family, as long as it’s consistent and within the parameters set by your treatment center.

content: We were given our allergen in powder form in the beginning, and the team trained me how to accurately measure the doses by grams. My biggest piece of advice is to measure out your OIT doses in advance, at least one week’s worth at a time. I do this every Sunday with my weekly meal prep, and it makes life so much easier. Once you move into real foods (for example, my son eats pretzels for his wheat dose and milk for his dairy dose), I pre-measure those as well. This makes it easy on me and also possible for a babysitter or other caregiver to manage dosing as needed.

We food allergy parents are already well versed in planning ahead. I promise you can totally do this. But the last important piece to consider is what your child thinks of treatment. If they are babies or young children, this is an absolute no-brainer. You can treat them before they even remember having a food allergy!  But if they are older, you do want their buy-in. This will affect their daily lives for a long time, and the road will be easier for you both if you are on the same page.

content: My boys were 8 and 10 years old when we started, old enough to be  a part of the decision process. They both knew it would be a ton of work, but they both wanted less restriction and fear in their lives. And like I said before, even though my younger son has had a few reactions to his treatment, he is all in to keep going because he knows how much his life has already changed for the better.
What to Look for in a Treatment Center
So how do you choose a treatment center? I can assure you they are not all created equal.  Let’s look at the options and considerations as you research what might work best for your family.

One way to receive treatment is to be involved in a clinical trial. This is an incredibly noble way to get treatment because you become part of important science that will affect our entire community. We owe so much of where we are today to many clinical trials and participants that came before us. If you are interested in researching local clinical trials, check the research hospitals near you. Keep in mind that you will likely have to start with an oral food challenge, even if your blood and skin testing are high. You might end up going through the trial and find out you were on a placebo (a fake treatment given for research purposes).  And you can’t personalize your program because it will be dictated by the trial parameters.

There are more allergists practicing oral immunotherapy than ever before, although the number overall is still pretty low. Many private allergy clinics are offering single allergen OIT – treatment of one allergen at a time. From personally researching options, I’ve learned these private clinics often usually stop at that initial “low dose” maintenance level (for example, one peanut) and don’t push beyond that. If your child has a smaller list of allergies, or you are happy with cross-contamination clearance, this might be a great option for you – especially if you don’t have access to a larger, specialty clinic.

content: As I mentioned earlier, single dose OIT didn’t make sense for our family. We just had too many allergies to work through them one at a time. We were grateful to find a specialty food allergy treatment center that offered multi-allergen OIT. My boys are treated at Latitude Food Allergy Care, which now has six offices in the San Francisco and New York City area. I felt comforted knowing that their protocols came directly out of work done by Dr. Kari Nadeau at Stanford University. Proven clinical research and transparency were hugely important to me when choosing a treatment clinic. (Disclosure: I serve on the Board of Directors for Latitude, but I share my experience solely as a food allergy parent.)
The Future for OIT is Bright

The most important takeaway for you is this: There are options! We are so lucky to live in a time where we do have treatment opportunities. We’ve even had two huge FDA approvals recently: peanut allergen powder (Palforzia) for peanut OIT, and Xolair to treat food allergies by reducing reactions that may occur after accidentally ingesting an allergen. There is no better time than now to have an in-depth conversation with your allergist about what might be the best fit for your child.

content: Food allergy treatment is not one-size-fits-all – and neither are allergists or practices. So, my best advice is to find the right doctor/clinic for your family, make sure you properly test your food allergens so you are confident of your “real” list of allergies, and then move forward with treatment if you choose.  Do your research and trust your gut. Only you know what’s best for your child and your family.

We’ve had a long journey so far, and we still have a road ahead. But I wouldn’t change our choice to pursue OIT. Our two tales are both success stories… and I can’t wait to see what our future holds. I wish you luck as you consider your own treatment options. You’ve got this!

content: Author’s note: I am not a doctor and this is not medical advice.  I am sharing what I’ve learned over my 12 years as a food allergy mom and three years managing my son’s OIT treatment. Please consult a board-certified allergist when making medical decisions.
Photo Credit: JGI/Tom Grill / Getty Images
